roeddaf yn King's Road, yn Llanda Beir NO 1932,

I left school at 14 and then I was in a factory in Almondford for almost a year and then I left there because it was Pullman Springfield factory making the springs of bedding.
Well, they were all in coils and I was a feeder basically, they called it a feeder, just unpacking all the springs and presenting them to the ladies that crimped them up for the form of bedding.
So I left there and I was chased off with that, I wanted to become a motor mechanic so I went then to a garage in Llandebier called Morgan Jenkins and Sons to start my apprenticeship until I went into the army at 18 and my brother and I were called up at the same time.
My brother remained in the factory in Almondford and then he left later on and became, he passed his driving test and was a butter salesman for Harris the Butter Merchant in Llandebier.
They were friends with Ellis the Butter Merchant in Fairbach and I went to, after coming out of the army, I joined the RSE as a RSE patrol.
And then I, you've got me.
Yes, so a RSE patrol man.
Yes, my distance was from Llandefri all the way down to Morriston Cross and back twice a day basically.
I met up with an RSE patrol man in Llandefri, just outside Llandefri towards Brecon.
And after that then I, or later on, I worked for the steel company in Gorsaynend for a year and then I left that and then I became a bus driver then for six and a half years with South Wales Transport and Double Deckers and Single Deckers.
I was on coach driving as well towards Blackpool and Bournemouth and different places.
The elderly, I used to sing on the mic in the bus and the coach then and all the old age people used to enjoy it and they always used to ask for Dawn.
And the day the dentist and his wife on the front seat next to me on my left was, I didn't have to worry about my breathing because yesterday he had a big map on his lap and he said, left you had Dawn, right you had Dawn and all the way wherever I wanted to go.
He was a fantastic navigator.
What's the word? A navigator, yes.
And after that I went to, with the National Coal Board as a driver for five years later on and then I applied for a job as a foreman.
I didn't think I'd get it but out of 18 drivers tried it, the general manager gave it to me and I was told, we'll break you within three months and I was a foreman for ten years.
So I finished then after the closure of the pits and Mrs Thatcher came along and said bye bye to you all.
I lost £12,000 then on the, I lost £12,000 wages basically but never mind.
So after that then my mother was not very well and my parents and so between everything then I, between arthritis and other problems I had and then that was it and here I am now.
I stayed in the TA during that time.
Yes.
It was in 1950 when you and your twin brother got called up for National Service.
Well basically we were called up and did our training in Derring Lines in Brecon and during the career training and then we were doing some career training in Cwmgywdi at the mountain rescue places.
I think I'm not sure but and then we were on draft then for career or Belize in Central America and so we were all on the main square with all the streets and bedfords.
We were all in line picking different people up and my brother and I were by the tailboard of the lorry basically.
The other guys were getting up onto the vehicle and we were told that you're not going, you must report to the officers mess.
So we went up to the officers mess and that's where basically we stayed.
We became waiters and then.
What was the reason for you being called back?
The reason was that somebody had decided to send us up.
I don't know who it was but unknown to myself and my brother years.
I almost finished with the tears.

I have no idea.
